body.seg: 20th ANNUAL REPORT OF THE STATE TAX COMMISSIONER AND THE State Board of Equalization and Assessment STATE OF NEBRASKA 1940'

MEMBERS OF THE BOARD ROY L. COCHRAN Governor HARRY R. SWANSON Secretary of State RAY C.JOHNSON State Auditor JOHN HAVEKOST State Treasurer WM. H. SMITH State Tax Commissioner LEGAL ADVISER TO THE BOARD WALTER R. JOHNSON -.Attorney General EDWIN VAIL Assistant TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the Consti - tution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commissioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Com - missioner under the constitutional provisions are: Name County Served W. H. OSBORNE Custer April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923, to January 12, 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton...January 12, 1925, to January 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT...Lancaster..January 8, 1929, to December 1, 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward January 8, 1931, to OFFICE STAFF—-1940 Florence Thomas Chief Clerk Edna Wellman —Distribution Clerk Irene Walters Tax Clerk Alice McCormick Bookkeeper Minnie Adsit ....Clerk-Bookkeeper Marjorie Heyne Stenographer Bureau of Purchase and Supplies J. R. Farr's -..Purchasing Agent Helen Werner Stenographer Mary Burke Clerk

LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER ¦'„;.": LINCOLN, NEBRASKA ; : . December 1, 1940. Honorable R. L. Cochran, ¦¦''; Governor of Nebraska, . ¦;. Lincoln. , ' . ' . My dear Governor: • ; There is being transmitted to you herewith the annual report of the State Board of-Equalization and Assessment, and the State Tax Com - missioner, for the year 1940. In addition to tables showing the result of the general assessment of various classes of property for the current year, the report carries a statement showing the expenditures from all sources and for all purposes, as shown by the records of the department, and a statement showing the gasoline tax collections and disbursements to counties. REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMEN NO. 5 ROLLING STOCK ASSESSMENT The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in Accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided bv the total number of miles, giving the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the County Clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and then equalized bv the State Board. STATE OF NEBRASKA IN CONCLUSION There is omitted from this report the final table assembled from the footings of the tax lists submitted by the county clerks for the reason that not all of them have as yet been received. This is the table showing the total taxes levied by counties, for state, county, city, and village, school and miscellaneous purposes. It is my desire to have the work of the de - partment as nearly completed as possible before the change in administra - tion in January, hence the conclusion to complete the printing of the report without the final table. A supplemental report giving the information may be issued when the data is all available. Valuation Trends The valuation of all the tangible property of the state for taxation purposes has decreased from $3,102,050,571, in 1930 to $1,922,271,788 in 1940, the decrease amounting to 38.03 per cent. The decrease in the valuation of lands and improvements; which is included in the foregoing, has been in excess of the average decrease for all property in that it has amounted to 40.54 per cent, the valuation in 1930 having been fixed at $1,736,632,780 whereas in 1940 it was found by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to be $1,032,542,666. Prior to 1933 the law provided that real estate should be revalued for taxation purposes each four years, and the last assessment under that law was made in 1930 when the value was found to be $46,128,595 less than was found in 1929. As a result of the continued adverse economic conditions, there was a demand in 1932 for a general reduction in the assessed value of lands and improvements and while the law did not authorize it, the State Board of Equalization and Assesssment arbitrarily approved a re - valuation that resulted in a reduction of $301,153,484 from the previous year's total as returned by the assessors. As a matter of fairness to other classes of property and to avoid a possible basis for litigation, they were treated in line with lands and improvements and as a result no litigation followed. Had litigation developed, it might have invalidated the entire assessment. In 1933 the law was amended by the legislature to provide for a reassessment in 1933 and again in 1934 and every two years thereafter. It is this law under which the state is operating at the present time. Following its passage, there was an additional reduction in the valuation of lands arid improvements of $287,257,385 in that year from the valuation in 1932, and a further reduction of $7,570,753 when the reassessment was made in 1934. ¦•¦¦ The decrease in the value of all property in 1940 from the 1939 value totaled $125,247,803 or 6.1. per cent, whereas the decrease in the value of lands and improvements alone amounted to $86,858,277 or 8.5 per cent.
